name: Integrate Asana on CloudEagle into Your KSAT Console
title: Integrate Asana on CloudEagle into Your KSAT Console
body:
You can integrate your Asana on the CloudEagle platform into your KSAT console. Integrating these apps with KSAT allows you to access detailed information about organizations, view user lists, manage user accounts, and monitor accurate usage of the Asana platform through user login activity.

Note:To monitor usage of the Asana platform, Asana Enterprise+ or Asana Legacy Enterprise plans are required.

Before You Connect Asana on CloudEagle to Your KSAT Console

Before integrating Asana on CloudEagle into your KSAT console, you must create a KnowBe4 Reporting API token and save it in a safe location for use in the following steps. For more information on KnowBe4’s Reporting API tokens, see our Reporting API Overview article.

Connecting Asana on CloudEagle to Your KSAT Console

You can connect your Asana on the CloudEagle platform to your KSAT console by following the steps below.

  1. Log in to your Asana account and navigate to the admin console.
  2. In the left navigation menu, select Apps.
  3. Select Add Service account and create a new service account for the CloudEagle integration.
  4. Enter a name for your service account, and in Permission scopes, select User provisioning (SCIM) and Audit Logs.

  5. Add your KnowBe4 Reporting API token, and then select Save changes when complete.
  6. To connect Asana Enterprise users, create a service account token from the Asana app that is associated with an Asana Enterprise+ or an Asana Legacy Enterprise account.
  7. Log in to your CloudEagle platform and navigate to Admin > Integrations > Direct Integrations. Search for Asana Enterprise. Select Connect.

  8. A new window will open asking for a Personal Access Token. Paste the token you saved from the previous step into the space provided and select Connect.

  9. If the connection is successful, you will see a Sync Now button. Select Sync Now to start syncing the data.

  10. The first sync may take some time, depending on the size of the data. You will receive a notification after the sync is complete. Data syncs will automatically occur every 24 hours to ensure you have the latest updates.
  11. Once the first data sync is complete, you can view all the information you have given access to in the Asana Enterprise Application tab, under Current Data Source, as Direct Integration.

  12. You can also use the Users module to provision or deprovision Asana Enterprise to users and manage them directly from the License Management tab.

images.alt:
The image displays the Asana Admin console, specifically the **Service accounts** page, with a modal dialog overlaying the content.

**Contextual Background UI:**
*   The application is **Asana ADMIN**.
*   The active navigation link in the left sidebar is **Service accounts** (under the Apps section).
*   The main page title is **Service accounts**.

**Modal Dialog Description:**
A centrally positioned modal dialog titled **Add service account** is active, dimming the background UI. It contains input fields for defining a new service account:

1.  **Name:** A required single-line text input (content obscured).
2.  **Description:** A multi-line text area (empty).
3.  **Permission scopes:** A section dedicated to assigning access rights.
    *   Informational Text: "Scopes define what your app can access..." with a linked option: **Learn more about scopes**.
    *   **Permission Selection (Radio Buttons):**
        *   **Scoped permissions:** Selected.
        *   **Full permissions:** Unselected.
    *   **Scoped Permission Options (Checkboxes):** Visible because "Scoped permissions" is selected.
        *   User provisioning (SCIM)
        *   Audit Logs
        *   Exporting
        *   *Note: All three checkbox options are currently unchecked.*

**Action Buttons:**
The modal footer contains two actions:
1.  **Cancel** (Standard button).
2.  **Save changes** (Grayed out/disabled, indicating the service account setup is incomplete).

This image displays a single row entry from a software application table interface, detailing information about a specific vendor and application.

**Table Structure (Header Row):**
The table columns are labeled:
1.  **Application**
2.  **Vendor**
3.  **Category**
4.  **Vendor Spend (Last 12 Months)**
5.  **Status**
6.  **Last Sync**
7.  **Actions**

**Data Row Content (Asana Enterprise):**
The displayed row contains data for the "Asana Enterprise" application:
*   **Application:** Asana Enterprise (in blue, indicating a clickable link).
*   **Vendor:** The Asana logo icon followed by the text "Asana".
*   **Category:** Project Management Software.
*   **Vendor Spend (Last 12 Months):** ₹0 (Rupee symbol followed by zero).
*   **Status:** Not Connected.
*   **Last Sync:** (Blank).
*   **Actions:** A light blue bordered button labeled "Connect" and a vertical ellipsis icon (three dots) indicating additional options.

The image displays a modal dialog titled **"Connect: Asana Enterprise"** used for integrating the application via credentials.

**UI Elements and Content:**

1.  **Header:** Displays the title "Connect: Asana Enterprise" with an Asana logo icon on the left and a close button (X) on the right.
2.  **Instructions:** A bulleted list, headed **"Instructions to connect Asana Enterprise on CloudEagle,"** provides a 7-step guide for generating the required token.
    *   **Prerequisite:** Requires a personal access token (PAT) from a service account under the Asana Enterprise+ or Legacy plan.
    *   **Steps include:** Logging into the Asana admin console, creating a service account, selecting specific permission scopes (**"User provisioning (SCIM)"** and **"Audit Logs"**), copying the generated token, and pasting it below.
3.  **Input Field:** A required input field labeled **"Service Account Personal Access Token (PAT) \*"** is present, with the placeholder text "Service Account Personal Access Token (P..."
4.  **Action Buttons (Footer):** Two buttons are displayed: "Cancel" (light blue outline) and "Connect" (light gray, appears disabled pending token input).
images.context: step into the space provided and select Connect.

images.alt:
This image displays a single data entry row from a multi-column application management table.

**Table Structure (Headers, left to right):**
1. Application
2. (Partial column header, ending in "last 12 Months)")
3. Status
4. Last Sync
5. Usage
6. Provisioning
7. Users
8. Usage (Second instance of the header)
9. Actions

**Data Row Content (Under "Asana Enterprise"):**
*   **Application:** The application name is listed as "Asana Enterprise" (displayed as a blue hyperlink).
*   **Cost/Metric:** The value is "₹0".
*   **Status:** The connection status is "Connected".
*   **Last Sync:** The timestamp for the last synchronization is "06/05/2024 06:26 pm".
*   **Usage (Primary):** Usage is displayed as a horizontal bar showing near-zero fill, followed by the text "0%", and a circular icon containing a cloud or tree symbol.
*   **Provisioning:** Status is indicated by a green circular icon containing a checkmark (implying successful provisioning).
*   **Users:** Status is indicated by a green circular icon containing a checkmark.
*   **Usage (Secondary):** Status is indicated by a green circular icon containing a checkmark.
*   **Actions:** Contains a primary action button labeled "Sync Now" (white background, blue border, blue text), followed immediately by a vertical ellipsis icon, indicating a drop-down or context menu for additional actions.
images.context: Select Sync Now to start syncing the data.

images.alt:
This image displays a software management dashboard focused on "Asana Enterprise by Asana." The primary view is the **"License Management"** tab, which is currently active.

**Header and Navigation:**
*   The application title is "Asana Enterprise by Asana."
*   A horizontal navigation bar contains the following tabs (from left to right, with the active tab underlined): Need Action, Usage, **License Management**, General Info, Spend Details, Benchmarking, Security Profile, Messaging, Workflow, and an overflow menu (...).
*   In the upper right corner, there are two action buttons: "Add Comments" and "Start Access Review."

**Data Source Selection (Highlighted Area):**
*   Located beneath the main title bar is a data selection control labeled **"Current Data Source."**
*   The selected value in the dropdown menu is **"Direct Integration."**

**License Info Section:**
*   This section displays key metrics under the heading "License Info."
*   **LICENSES BOUGHT:** Displays an "Add licenses" hyperlink.
*   **PROVISIONED USERS:** Displays the value **"116"** (hyperlinked).
*   **PLAN TYPE:** Displays a dash ("-").
*   An edit icon (pencil) is present in the top right of this section.

**License Details Section:**
*   The subsection heading is "License Details."
*   A dropdown selector shows **"20 selected."**
*   A large area below is dedicated to a time-series graph (area chart).
*   The Y-axis ranges from 0 to 70 in increments of 7.
*   The X-axis displays dates ranging from 05/06 (June 5th) to 13/06 (June 13th).
*   The graph legend lists numerous organizational departments or user types, indicating a breakdown of licensed users: Advertising, DevOps, Engineering, Finance, Human Resources (HR), Marketing, Marketing GS Dept, Marketing Gs Dept, No Department, Operation, SaaS Buyers, Sales, and Support.
*   Chart interaction controls (zoom in, zoom out, pan/hand tool, reset view) are visible above the top right corner of the graph.

This document describes a user interface (UI) screen centered on application license management.

**Context and Navigation:**

*   **Application Header:** Displays the application title "Asana Enterprise by Asana."
*   **Top-Level Navigation Tabs:** The current active view is **License Management**. Other visible tabs include Need Action, Usage, General Info, Spend Details, Benchmarking, Security Profile, Messaging, and Workflow.
*   **Header Action:** A button labeled "Add Comments" is visible in the top right corner.

**Visualization (Graph Panel):**

*   A line graph displays usage metrics over time, spanning dates from 05/06 to 13/06.
*   The Y-axis shows numerical counts (0 to 63).
*   The graph legend identifies various departments or groups (e.g., Advertising, DevOps, Engineering, Finance, Human Resources (HR), Marketing) associated with the tracked metrics.

**User Management Controls:**

*   **Search and Filter:** A "Search Users" bar is present, accompanied by a dedicated filter icon and a "Default View" dropdown.
*   **Active Filter Chip:** A filter chip labeled **Provisioned = Yes** is active, alongside a "Clear All" button.
*   **User Count:** A status indicator shows **116 of 116 Users**.
*   **Primary System Action:** A prominent blue button allows users to **Upload License File**.

**Data Grid and User Actions:**

*   **Action Bar (Applicable to Selected Users):** Three main action buttons are displayed above the data grid: **Deprovision Users** (primary blue action), **Send Mail**, and **Confirm Access**.
*   **Data Grid Columns:** The grid includes columns for user data:
    *   User
    *   Email
    *   License Type
    *   Role
    *   Provisioned On
    *   Provisioned
    *   Last Logged In
    *   Last Activity
*   **User Selection:** Checkboxes allow selection. The visible entries for Anju and Clark Ngo are currently selected (checked), both showing "Yes" under the Provisioned column.
images.context: manage them directly from the License Management tab.
